articles.headline: Labor Secretary Faces Demands to Resign Over Epstein Plea Deal
articles.snippet: Mr. Acosta is facing an uproar over the role he played in a lenient plea deal with the New York financier Jeffrey Epstein over sex crimes.
articles.abstract: Mr. Acosta is facing an uproar over the role he played in a lenient plea deal with the New York financier Jeffrey Epstein over sex crimes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Labor Secretary R. Alexander Acosta on Tuesday faced fresh calls to resign, and rising pressure from inside the Trump administration, over his role in brokering a lenient plea deal over sex crimes for the New York financier Jeffrey E. Epstein as a federal prosecutor in Miami more than a decade ago.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Patricia Mazzei

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Watchdog Is Preparing to Deliver Verdict on the Russia Investigation
articles.snippet: Investigators for the inspector general recently interviewed Christopher Steele, the former British spy, as they try to determine whether the F.B.I. misstepped in the inquiry.
articles.abstract: Investigators for the inspector general recently interviewed Christopher Steele, the former British spy, as they try to determine whether the F.B.I. misstepped in the inquiry.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Inside a London office building in early June, three investigators for the Justice Department’s inspector general took a crucial step toward clearing the political fallout from the Russia investigation: They spent two days interviewing Christopher Steele, the former British spy whose now-infamous dossier of purported links between Trump associates and Russia ended up in the hands of the F.B.I. ahead of the 2016 election.
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman, Charlie Savage and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: The Jeffrey Epstein Case Was Cold, Until a Miami Herald Reporter Got Accusers to Talk
articles.snippet: The case seemed cold when a Miami Herald investigative journalist started looking into it. Then she persuaded accusers to tell their stories.
articles.abstract: The case seemed cold when a Miami Herald investigative journalist started looking into it. Then she persuaded accusers to tell their stories.
articles.lead_paragraph: Julie K. Brown, an investigative journalist for The Miami Herald, expected to spend the week on the same emotionally brutal endeavor she has pursued for more than two years: interviewing women who say that, as girls, they were part of a sex ring run by the wealthy financier Jeffrey Epstein.

articles.headline: 35 Employees Committed Suicide. Will Their Bosses Go to Jail?
articles.snippet: After a wave of worker suicides under their management, former executives at France Télécom have been charged with the crime of “moral harassment.”
articles.abstract: After a wave of worker suicides under their management, former executives at France Télécom have been charged with the crime of “moral harassment.”
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — In their blue blazers and tight haircuts, the aging men look uncomfortable in the courtroom dock. And for good reason: they are accused of harassing employees so relentlessly that workers ended up killing themselves.

articles.headline: You’re Hired. Now Wear This Headset to Learn the Job.
articles.snippet: Companies like Microsoft see a multibillion-dollar opportunity to get more personal technology to workers who don’t sit behind a desk.
articles.abstract: Companies like Microsoft see a multibillion-dollar opportunity to get more personal technology to workers who don’t sit behind a desk.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHILLICOTHE, Ohio — When Toby Bouska Jr. started assembling cabs for Kenworth semitrucks last year, he learned the ropes by observing longtime workers at the factory. But it wasn’t exactly engaging, and he didn’t get much practice doing the job himself.

articles.headline: She Was Duped and Shipped to a Brothel at 16. Then the Boat Sank.
articles.snippet: In April, a boat smuggling dozens of people out of Venezuela, some entrapped by a human trafficking ring, capsized in the sea on the way to Trinidad. Only nine people survived.
articles.abstract: In April, a boat smuggling dozens of people out of Venezuela, some entrapped by a human trafficking ring, capsized in the sea on the way to Trinidad. Only nine people survived.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHAGUARAMAS, Trinidad and Tobago — She slipped out of the house around dusk, without telling her mother. Sixteen and hungry, she followed the men who had promised her work and food.

articles.headline: The Fish Is Boneless. (Fishless, Too.)
articles.snippet: Several companies are developing sustainable, plant-based or laboratory-made seafood alternatives. It might help the planet, but will anyone eat it?
articles.abstract: Several companies are developing sustainable, plant-based or laboratory-made seafood alternatives. It might help the planet, but will anyone eat it?
articles.lead_paragraph: First, there was the meatless burger. Soon we may have fishless fish.

articles.headline: Fed Chair Powell Signals Rate Cut as Economic Risks Loom
articles.snippet: Jerome H. Powell sent stock markets higher with comments that trade tensions and global economic issues continue to weigh on the United States economy.
articles.abstract: Jerome H. Powell sent stock markets higher with comments that trade tensions and global economic issues continue to weigh on the United States economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve chair, Jerome H. Powell, signaled on Wednesday that the Fed could soon cut interest rates, sending stocks higher as the benchmark S&P 500 stock index briefly traded above 3,000 for the first time.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Matt Phillips

articles.headline: Amazon HQ2 Is Upending Northern Virginia’s Already Unstable Housing Market
articles.snippet: Homeowners are getting bombarded by speculators asking them to sell. Tenants are fighting rent increases. And Amazon hasn’t even started building.
articles.abstract: Homeowners are getting bombarded by speculators asking them to sell. Tenants are fighting rent increases. And Amazon hasn’t even started building.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Amazon has yet to break ground in Northern Virginia for its second headquarters, but residents are already turning away persistent speculators, recalculating budgets for down payments on homes and fighting rent increases.

articles.headline: Harvard Suspends Roland Fryer, Star Economist, After Sexual Harassment Claims
articles.snippet: The move sidelines the researcher without pay for two years, and closes his lab, in a case that has roiled the profession.
articles.abstract: The move sidelines the researcher without pay for two years, and closes his lab, in a case that has roiled the profession.
articles.lead_paragraph: Roland G. Fryer, a onetime rising star in economics who has been accused by several women of sexual harassment, will lose his Harvard University research lab and be suspended for two years, the university said Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Trump Rolls Out the Red Carpet for Right-Wing Social Media Trolls
articles.snippet: A White House gathering on Thursday illuminates the influence of President Trump’s Twitter fans within the political establishment. But it also has the makings of a West Wing pity party.
articles.abstract: A White House gathering on Thursday illuminates the influence of President Trump’s Twitter fans within the political establishment. But it also has the makings of a West Wing pity party.
articles.lead_paragraph: Trolling on the internet was once a thankless pastime. Make edgy jokes on the right message board, get your sarcastic memes noticed by the right people, and you might score some retweets and Reddit upvotes, but that was about the extent of it.
